history.content:
For computer vision, definitely useful. Maybe not at the undergraduate level though. If you've taken 184 they talk about this, but you can view an image as a signal. The same signal processing operations done on images (DCT compression, filtering of various types, etc) are based in signals, and while I haven't done a pure computer vision course yet (hoping to take the grad level one next semester), as you can see from here they use signal/frequency representations in later lectures. Not the core course to take if you're interested in computer vision at the undergraduate level, but it would be useful.

As a systems person, probably not too useful though, though computer vision isn't career-useful as a systems person either. I do find it a good class, especially with Babak (he's great). It also is basically an intro course to a whole half of EE, so you get that exposure, and those kind of intro courses are also paradigm-building in the sense that they can shape how you analyze stuff. So like totally, take it if you want. But career benefits for a systems person, you'd be better off with EE 122 (the EE version of 168). 

If you're looking for classes in EE in general that will help with systems, maybe the stuff at the border of EE and CS, like 149, might be more career beneficial. But hey, you're in college. It's ok to try stuff that isn't 100% what you are looking to do for work.

children.subject: Pretty good response. I thank you for the time you took to write that! The deal is that I am a transfer student so I don't get the benefit of time to explore too much. I really want to take ee120 with Babak but it overlaps with one of my CS classes next spring. I will graduate next fall, but if I find a way to extend my stay here then I will take those classes!

history.content: Hello, by the end of next semester i will have completed cs186, cs62, cs61 and maybe cs168. I want to explore computer vision / ML en my last semester (cs189, cs182, or ee225b). I have planned to *maybe* take ee127 and stat140 (ee126 is no big NO). So do you think ee120 will add some substantial benefit as a cs-systems-focused person?
history.subject: Do you think taking EE120 offers benefits if I an focusing into CS systems?
